in 1897 in the Maharashtra District of
India however when his father died in
1915 nisargdatta moved the family to
Bombay where with his brother he opened
a string of eight small goods shops
selling mainly berries or Leaf rolled
cigarettes in 1923 he married and in the
years that followed he and his wife had
three daughters and a son in 1933
nisargdatta's life would change forever
it was in that year that nasar datta met
his Guru siddhar rameshwar Maharaja
siddhar rameshwar Maharaj was a guru in
the lineage of the inchigeri sampradaya
also known as nimbargi sampraday this
lineage of teachers came from
Maharashtra and were inspired by a
number of great spiritual teachers
including the great Mystic
was unique in that it offered spiritual
practice to people from all walks of
life including women and people of all
religions those who came for the
teachings did not even have to be
practicing Hindus it was particularly
popular with householders those with the
responsibilities of work and family in
fact the gurus of this lineage were
known for traveling from home to home to
make themselves available to
householders rather than the householder
having to make time to visit the guru
many years later the sarthatha would say
to his lineage the integeri sampraday I
sit here every day answering your
questions but this is not the way that
the teachers of my linears used to do
their work ours is a householder lineage
which means everyone had to go out and
earn his living there were no meetings
like this where disciples met in large
numbers with the guru and asked him
questions Trav level was difficult there
were no buses trains or planes in the
older days the guru did the traveling on
foot while the disciples stayed at home
and looked after their families the guru
walked from Village to Village to meet
the disciples when the guru knew that he
was about to pass away he would appoint
one of the householder devotees to be
the new Guru and that new Guru would
then take up on the teaching duties
walking from Village to Village
initiating new devotees and supervising
the progress of the old ones
it was this open attitude to all that
was evident in the small meeting room in
which Nissan met with Seekers of all
kinds from all over the world the guru
lineage of the enchageri sampraddai
would become known throughout the
Western world as nisargdatta Maharaja
became more and more well known around

Minnesota took siddharameshwar Maharaja
as his Guru siddharameshwar gave him a
mantra and some very straightforward
meditation instructions
followed exactly in the words of
nisargdatta my Guru ordered me to attend
to the sense I am and to give attention
to nothing else I just obeyed I did not
follow any particular course of
breathing meditation or study of
scriptures whatever happened I would
turn away my attention from it and
remain with the sense I am it may look
too simple even crude my only reason for
doing it was that my Guru told me so yet
it worked
his guru's meditation instructions in
any spare moment he had between his
responsibilities to his family and to
his business my Guru told me go back to
that state of pure being where the I am
is to still in its Purity before it got
contaminated with this I am or that I am
your burden is a false identifications
abandon them all I simply followed his
instructions which was to focus the mind
on pure being I am and stay in it I used
to sit for us together with nothing but
the I am in my mind and soon the peace
and joy and deep all embracing love
became my normal state in it all
disappeared myself my Guru the life I
lived and the world around me only peace
remained an unfathomable silence
for merely two and a half years until
siddharameshwar's death in 1936 after
his guru's death
entered a period of intense inquiry and

nasakdatta realized the self I realized

he would spend the rest of his life in

shifted the emphasis from Mantra

back consistently to the inherent
feeling of existing in other words to

said that I am was merely a Gateway the
aim of meditation of the felt sense of I
am was to reach the ultimate source
prior to the arising of the I
called this ultimate source power Brahma
he said that the feeling of I am arose
from conception with the appearance of
the body and was maintained by breath
and food take away bread and or food and
the feeling I am would soon disappear
the Ultimate Reality was not the I am in
fact I am is the primary illusion from
which all other illusion arises the
Ultimate Reality par Brahma is that
which is prior to the arising of the I
am simply put nisarg datta suggests
meditate on the feeling I am until the
illusory nature of I am is revealed the
Ultimate Reality
prior to I am is pure unbounded
awareness awareness however that is not
aware of itself it merely is
taught a three-staged hierarchy of
Consciousness first was the jeev Atma
this is the one who identifies himself
as a body and personality they stand
apart as an individual apart from the
world because they identify themselves
as their body mind second was beingness
or iamness this I am-ness can be known
or meditated upon it resolves
differences of self and world into its
singular beingness it is however egoity
in its purest form and the seed illusion
of separate self thus the illusory
nature of I am of beingness itself must
be realized it must be passed through
and gone beyond third was the ultimate
or par Brahma of the ultimate nothing
can be really said the closest pointer
would be non-being or nothingness or
emptiness or even pure awareness unaware
of itself however once we pass beyond
beingness or I am-ness words are
virtually useless it is this non-being
from which being or I am-ness arises and
falls back into non-being or the
ultimate is the ground that allows for
the rising of being
nisargata's practice was to meditate on
beingness or I am until its illusory
nature was realized thereby naturally
and effortlessly resting in the ultimate
or non-being or awareness unaware of
itself the Great Indian Saint and Sage
of the 20th century Ramana Maharishi
points to the ultimate in a very similar
to nisargdatta when he says anything
outside deep dreamless sleep is unreal

perhaps the two teachers who have had
the most effect on Western students of
advaithya vedanta or non-dualism over
the last 30 years have been nisarg datta
Maharaja and SRI Ramana Maharishi are
their teachings in any way similar do
they complement each other for many the
answer is yes Nissan tata's primary
message was mediate on the sense of I am
until the I am is seen to be illusory
ramana's primary message was to inquire
who am I the inquiry was suggested by
Ramana so that one might see very
clearly that there was in fact no I
present the one we presume to be
thinking our thoughts is actually only
itself a
thoughts that sense of I was a root
feeling of I am which is seen as
illusory we may get a better
understanding of what is being pointed
to by both teachers if we listen to
ramana's words about his own State
Ramana said that he was in the condition
of jagrat sushupti jagrat is the fully
awake state sushukti is the state of
Deep dreamless Sleep Ramana said that he
was both in jagrat and sushukti
simultaneously in other words jagrat
sushupti Ramana often pointed to the
state of deep dreamless sleep as
revealing or pointing to our real being
in fact Ramana said nothing outside deep
dreamless sleep is real and deep
dreamless sleep reveals to us the state
of true being of our true happiness feel
or imagine for a moment what Ramana
might mean by these words feel or
imagine the utter Bliss of deep
dreamless sleeps pure boundless freedom
from everything is there a worldly Bliss
that can match it now imagine that state
of blissful deep dreamless sleep and
being profoundly a way and completely
and utterly present hold on to that
feeling or imagination for a moment
imagine out of that state of profound
awakeness and the Bliss of deep
dreamless sleep that the feeling sense
of I am suddenly arises can you see or
feel why nasar datta called I Am the
primary illusion can you see or feel
that I am is the root of all sense of
separation and the pinching off of our
natural and inherent boundless Bliss can
you see that your life can unfold

on the sense of I am until the sense of
I am is seen to be illusory this called
the sense of I am Brahma the saddatta
called that which is prior to I am
